comments.commentBody: I believe Amy is dying and thus may be unavailable to chat with you.

Miracles do happen. And I wish from the bottom of my heart, like so many others here, and  everyone I believe who are touched by your life and your work,  that a miracle happens in your Life. May the miracle happen and  you continue to light up your loving husband ' s and your children 's lives for a long time.
A.H. what a gracious person you are yourself to write and reach out like this yourself at this time. You too are a part of eternal light and life.

Dear Amy,Jason,Justin,Miles, and Paris,

Your family is what our Lord wants for every one of His children to behold in their life. Unfortunately, that is not the case in most marriages. You are all immensely blessed.

If you allow me, I would like to give each of you something very special, but you won't know what it is until after you meet with God.

In addition I will continue to pray for each of you for the rest of my life and even up until you reach our Lord's presence.

Amy wrote the type of letter that I had so many times shared with my former husband. I loved him so immensely and completely that I, like so many women in love with their amazing husbands wanted for them, in our absence. That was back in the seventies that I had shared those thoughts with my late husband.

I know your family does not need a new wife, stepmom, they will be fine living with the memory of you Amy. I say this because I am alone now, and I love my life as it is. I love my grown children as well.

A man or a woman do not necessarily need to find another spouse, when the original one filled all the voids, and is now gone. That original fullness will last the survivor his/her lifetime, till he/she rejoins their first and only love, in eternity, with God's blessing!

God Bless all of you every single moment!

Sincerely,
Yolanda Hope Cavazos
That's what you took away from this love story? Whether the guy has money? Wow.

Dear Amy, I hope you know that you are an exquisite writer, an inspiring human being, and deserving of a miracle. There must have been more tears shed while reading your article than in any single piece published in the NYTimes. I am not a religious person, yet I found myself begging the powers-that-be to intervene on your behalf. The love you express is changing people's lives, and I will carry you in my heart forever. YOU are a miracle, and I wish I could find the words to thank you.
Delude yourself all you wish.

My "Jason" is Will--and your and my positions are switched; Will is the one with cancer. He was diagnosed with a pancreatic tumor on the same day you got your news, Amy. We'll be married 30 years on March 14. I am hoping he'll be here to hold hands with me. You are so brave.

Amy, I fear this might sound shallow as I intend initially to comment on the quality of your article, rather than on the depth surrounding your story, but I presume, that it's in the intermingling of both worlds -form and content- where the magnitude of this masterpiece resides. I  wept, even as I read at a coffee shop in my native Guatemala surrounded by many people. Your life story is aching, but I can't also help to think about how fortunate you have been to live it, better yet, to have created it, to be able to remember it in such way and to tell it; to have gathered such a beautiful story to narrate you. This, in all logical predicaments can't mean anything other than the fact that you are filled with beauty in your heart, in your mind, in your soul...Amy, you are a giant, may all the love you brought to this Earth be spread amongst us mortals, thanks for this beautiful story, may your days be filled with love!

Colonel Panic,

I wish for you JOY in every moment, absolutely understand the reference to self-pity. It is her best attempt to acknowledge the loneliness she feels through giving
her husband away while she is still alive. We are all afraid to die IMHO and perhaps
a contribution of Happiness will be forthcoming from how to enjoy life! May we all live in Love and support of each other. Smiles my friend : )

Bon voyage to you both.
May the road rise to meet you,
May the wind be always at your back.
May the sun shine warm upon your face,
The rains fall soft upon your fields.
And until we meet again,
May God hold you in the palm of his hand.

Words fail me Amy, I am sorry. Thank you for speaking to me and my husband. We will use this to be a better couple. Greatly saddened by your leaving Amy. Thank you for all you have given to us and so many others.

blessings,
Merrilee and Jeff

A wonderful 26 years. I imagine he would write
beautiful words about you. Sad for you that ovarian
cancer crossed your path.
Expect to be told you don't like puppies and kittens either.

I will miss you and I know you only from your letters! You brought me on the verge of tears, such a fairy tale should never end... In fact, it will never end. Your legacy is immense, your compassion is notable. I think your wonderful husband will surely require quite a while to even consider filling the empty space you leave behind. Peace and love forever! After all, we all only have what we give, and you have always be such a giving writer. Thank you!

I could have written this about my husband but heartbreakingly he was the one who died. He was as caring, genuine, kind and thoughtful as the man you describe here. My heart is as broken as your for not getting to spend my life nor carry out our plans with him. He died when my son was three so I have only stories to tell him. My wish is to again find a partner to build a life with. Ten years of trying have left me a bit jaded. Hard to replace what you have lost. You husband will need time to heal.
Many say you don't know what you had until it's gone. I disagree I loved and appreciated my husband like you do yours. We just never think they will be gone.
If that's the first thing in your mind after reading this, I truly feel sorry for you!
Thank you, Citizen!

So, so true. There is nothing like a wonderful partner to bring out the best in another. To the extent that I'm not a schlep, it is because of that wonderful other

The thing is, it doesn't have to be just your wife/husband/significant other who can bring this off. A very dear friend will do just as well.

Thank you, "AKR", for sharing your love for "J" with the rest of us.

This is reply to Mary ANC. How do you know AKR is "on her path"? She tatooed" more ". With the kind of love she is sharing with her husband and children, she deserves a miracle and more, much more time with them. And most important, THEY deserve more time with Amy. So medical miracles are perfectly in order here. Like many others (except you), I keep hoping a miracle will happen and AKR lives and loves here on earth for  years to come.

"Love is Strong as Death".

In the course of my life that quote (which I know mostly from a tower at a university I grew up near, not so much the bible) has meant many things to me over time. But when I read your essay Amy, I realized it meant just what you said here, all along.
I have a Jason, yet I also want your Jason.  I'm so sorry for your and Jason's loss...
polymorphous relationships can be VERY fulfilling! give it a try.
Is he open to men?  I'd love to meet him!

Dearest Amy, Your love story is a Valentine to TOP all Valentines.  You share your love for your sweet Jason, and your children.  Most of all, you give Jason the gift of peace, and guilt free courage to move forward in his right to love again.  Your love is supreme in its kindness and generosity . . . and certain selflessness.  How blessed you are to love so purely, and how blessed is Jason to be the object of your affections.  May God give you comfort and joy as you are set free from pain for all Eternity.  You are forever loved, and we, the readers, are filled with gratitude to you.  God bless, and godspeed, Amy.  Whenever I look to the stars, I will think of you.  XOXOXO
Dear Amy, I wish you a miracle...  but in the meanwhile all my best in the days going forward to you and your family.  Your story is beautiful.  What more can I say...  peace & love from Cape Cod.
